Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 05:44PM mocame wrote: I have had a couple of problems with anesthia/anesthesiologists. Usually, I have a problem coming out of it and all I want to do for the next day after my surgeries is sleep.  I have started to ask for a lighter anesthesia now. But during my Bilat Mastectomy, they gave me a pain block (instead of a pain pump that was originally prescribed) and all of the sudden everything went black and I started hallucinating.  They had to get me out of that and give me something else.  I only remember starting to again hear what they were saying and I could feel what they were doing, but I couldn't open my eyes.  Then they gave me something else and I don't remember anything until I woke up after the surgery.  According to my BS, when I was 45 minutes late for my surgery, she went to check on me and said I was out of it.  She thinks that they either gave me too much of the drug or I was really sensetive to it.  Either way, it was a wild and scary ride and I still remember it.  Since then I go with as light of anesthesia and I can.
Posts.Title: Anyone had anesthesia complications? pameliza pameliza

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 05:49PM mocame wrote: I have heard that laying on your left side will make it easier for the gas to pass.  I don't know if that's true or not but worth a try?!

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2009 05:56PM mocame wrote: I received a round pillow at my bs's office after a day of numerous biopsies.  I then used it after my bilateral mastectomy, each of my fills and after my reconstruction procedures.  I was told that a woman who had gone through a biopsy (it was benign, thank goodness) decided to make these for other women going through breast biopsies or surgeries.  I really appreciated it and thought about making some too.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 05:35PM mocame wrote: The day of my bilat. mastectomy was the last day I wore my ring.  It was on the tight side and hard to get off.  I too was afraid of the risk of lymphedema and stopped wearing it.   It looks funny when my husband and I go out.  He doesn't wear his ring either due to his line of work and the risk of it catching on a piece of machinery. When we go out, it looks like we're a couple that's still dating!

Posts.Content: May 28, 2011 03:54PM mocame wrote: Natalie, sorry you had to go through that.  That is a very trying and emotional day.  I know, I've gone through that too.  6 biopsies in one day (3 in each breast).  At least they're trying to be thorough and making sure they know what is there and what is not there.  Thankfully, my biopsies only showed cancer in one breast, not both.   Best wishes.
Posts.Title: On pins and needles again Eklypse Eklypse

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2008 08:00PM mocame wrote: For my Bilat Mastectomy, I was in the "Short Stay" unit at the hospital.  It's the same unit where all the outpatient surgeries are performed.  Actually, I was the exception because I stayed overnight while almost everyone went home from their respective types of surgeries.  My surgery started around noon and I went home the next day by 9:00AM.  It was fine and I was able to get more rest at home than at the hospital.  They also had set up a visiting nurse to check on me a couple times a week for 2 weeks.  They checked the incisions and called my doctors when I had a reaction to the antibiotic.  It really wasn't that bad and I was glad to be at home.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2009 05:31PM mocame wrote: I heard about that AFTER I had my surgery.  My surgery was in the two weeks before but I also do not put much weight on that theory.  There are so many reasons and (sometimes no reason it seems) as to why a person may develop breast cancer.  It may be a factor in helping someone survive longer or have less chance of recurrence and in others it may not.
Posts.Title: Timing your surgery - did your doctors talk to you about that? agnes121 mocame

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 09:07PM mocame wrote: I was diagnosed with multifocal DCIS, LCIS at the age of 38.  I was BRCA negative but my mom had bc 10 years before and there is extensive cancer throughout my mom's side of the family. I decided to have a bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction.  It wasn't an easy decision, especially since my husband only wanted me to have a unilateral.  He thought that you shouldn't get rid of something that didn't have anything wrong with it.  I understood that but this was me and how would I handle it if it came back in the other side?  I had been through a lot already. Besides having LCIS (giving me a higher risk of getting it in the other side), the deciding factor came when they found a suspicious lump in my good breast.  That overwhelming feeling of possibly having cancer in the other side and thinking about all I had already gone through is what helped make up my mind to have the bilateral. After a biopsy and then the mastectomy, they found that it wasn't cancer but I was fine with my decision. I have no regrets.  My reconstruction process is almost done.  I miss my real breasts but most days I don't even think about the fact that mine aren't real.  They look very real, especially in clothes.  My husband said they are almost too perfect and to look at me, nobody would know what all I went through.  I'm young yet and I have young children.  I needed to do what I can to be around the longest I possibly can and still have piece of mind.  Best wishes!
Posts.Title: What made you decide . . . Mantra Mantra

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2008 02:44AM mocame wrote: I started with bigger/oversized shirts/t-shirts so that I didn't have to reach so high to get my arms in the holes. I just gradually worked my way into tighter shirts from there. It felt good to be in more "normal" clothes. :)
Posts.Title: when can you wear clothes going on over head? rayhope sunflower45

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2008 09:51PM mocame wrote: Sherry, I was diagnosed with DCIS and LCIS. I had a bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction. My cancer was also close to the skin and they had to take more skin during my exchange surgery 4 months later to get a better margin. My onc recommended no chemo, radiation or Tamoxifen due to having had the Bilateral Mastectomies. They made that recommendation before I had the extra skin removed. So they didn't know for sure that there wasn't any more cancer there when they made that recommendation. Thankfully there wasn't. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: LCIS in margins after bilateral mast sherry64 karen9516

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2008 08:44PM mocame wrote: Sherry, Actually, I'm not sure if it was the DCIS or LCIS. I would have to check my path report and see if it says. My guess is it might be DCIS since I had a lot more of that than the LCIS.
Posts.Title: LCIS in margins after bilateral mast sherry64 karen9516

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2011 09:50PM mocame wrote: I have DCIS.  I had an excisional biopsy and they couldn't get clear margins.  Had a 2nd excisional biopsy, couldn't get clear margins.  They figured out that my DCIS was multi-focal and I decided on a bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction.  After the mastectomy they STILL didn't get big enough margins.  The cancer was really close to the skin so they took more skin during my exchange surgery.
